utterances.speaker: TUCKER CARLSON, HOST
utterances.utterance: Good evening and welcome to "Tucker Carlson Tonight." It has been more than a week since the last votes were cast in the 2018 midterms that was last Tuesday. But still, several big races remain unresolved at this hour. In the State of Florida, recount is ongoing. We'd have more on that in just a minute. It's pretty weird story. But perhaps, strangest of all is what is happening right now in Georgia. The race for Governor of Georgia was tight for months. You probably followed it. But it finished in the end pretty much exactly where the polls predicted it would finish. The Republican, Brian Kemp, defeated the Democrat Stacey Abrams by about 1.5 percentage points. In a big state, that is an awful lot of votes. For reasons she hasn't really explained those, Stacey Abrams has refused to accept those results. Her allies are now claiming the election was stolen.

utterances.speaker: SHERROD CAMPBELL BROWN, SENIOR UNITED STATES SENATOR, OHIO
utterances.utterance: If Stacey Abrams doesn't win in Georgia, they stole it. It's clear. It's clear.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Right (ph).

utterances.speaker: CORY ANTHONY BOOKER, JUNIOR UNITED STATES SENATOR, NEW JERSEY
utterances.utterance: Stacey Abrams election is being stolen from her using what I think are insidious measures to disenfranchise certain groups of people.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER FIRST LADY OF THE UNITED STATES, AMERICAN POLITICIAN, DIPLOMAT
utterances.utterance: I know Stacey well. She was one of my really strong surrogates in the campaign. If she'd had a fair election, she already would have won.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Election fraud. That's what they're saying. By the way, is there anyone more fraudulent than Cory Booker? Think about that. But back to election fraud, it's a serious charge. And it's telling that nobody making that charge has provided any evidence that it actually happened. No detail at all. Most remarkable of all though is that Hillary Clinton is one of the voices in this chorus. We keep track, and we remember Hillary's view just two years ago. Here's what she thought of losing candidates who claim the election is rigged.

utterances.speaker: CLINTON
utterances.utterance: That's horrifying. You know, every time Donald thinks things are not going in his direction, he claims whatever it is it's rigged against him. That is not the way our democracy works. We've been around for 240 years. We've had free and fair elections. We've accepted the outcomes when we may not have liked them. He is denigrating, he's talking down our democracy. And I, for one, am appalled.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: She's appalled. You got to accept the outcomes you don't like. But it turns out that accepting outcomes you don't like is something only Republicans are required to do. Richard Nixon had an entire presidential election stolen from him by JFK in 1960. Liberals applauded when Nixon chose not to contest that election. But Democrats do not apply the same standard to themselves. When Democrats lose, there is always a reason, a reason that has nothing to do with alienating voters or getting fewer votes. It's Putin rigged the machines. The Macedonians hacked Facebook. Roger Stone sent unapproved tweets, or the perennial favorite, you're racist, all of you who didn't vote for us, you're racist, you're immoral bigots. And, of course, that's what we're hearing once again now. By the way, it's a lie. America is not a racist country. It's a kind and decent country. But the Left hopes that by calling you enough names they'll bully you into giving them more power. They always try that and sometimes it works. It might work this time. The question is what's the cost to the country? Peter Kirsanow is U.S. Civil Rights Commissioner, a frequent guest on this show. He joins us again tonight. Peter, thanks a lot for coming on. So, first as a factual question--

utterances.speaker: PETER KIRSANOW, ATTORNEY, UNITED STATES COMMISSION ON CIVIL RIGHTS MEMBER, FORMER NATIONAL LABOR RELATIONS BOARD MEMBER
utterances.utterance: Hi, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --this is someone who's a rigorous thinker, I think, and has been following this, is there evidence, real evidence that Stacey Abrams has had this election stolen from her?

utterances.speaker: KIRSANOW
utterances.utterance: There's absolutely no evidence that I think anyone's adduced. But what we're seeing here, I think, is a test run for the 2020 election. It's not merely a test run. They're doing this in this election. They've done it in previous elections, although I will say that I don't think in my nearly two decades on the Civil Rights Commission, I've seen the intensity of the type of over-naked racial appeals and identity politics appeals that I've seen in this election cycle. And perhaps, you could go back even before the 1957 Civil Rights Act to the deep south, Orval Faubus, Lester Maddox, George Wallace and there's a reason for it. There are several reasons for it. But one is it works, and they were trying to delegitimize the election in advance. But it's a test run because think about how difficult it is for your average Leftist to try to convince a voter that they should accept their unworkable or somehow nutty, sometimes nutty politics or policy prescriptions--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KIRSANOW
utterances.utterance: --versus simply saying that person's a racist, that person is a bad person, all the right-thinking people know that person's a racist, and it has an ancillary effect that is it keeps Blacks on the Democratic reservation. This is existential for the Democratic Party. They need at least 90 percent of the Black vote just to be competitive, and even 90 percent plus of the Black vote. And so, they engage in these types of maneuvers and rhetoric on a regular basis. But the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: But - but wait (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KIRSANOW
utterances.utterance: --additional effect that's - that's helpful is it makes, and I think you alluded to this, there is a certain subset of White voters who they - they also want to align themselves with the right-thinking folks--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KIRSANOW
utterances.utterance: --and they don't want to be aligned with those that all the right-thinking people say are racist or despicable. So, to feel good about themselves, they'll vote in the prescribed manner.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right. And - and you're absolutely right that it - it works and they've been doing it an awfully long time. But I think in almost 30 years of covering elections, I've never seen it at this volume. You - you just a second ago said there are a couple of reasons for it. The first is it works and I agree with you. What are the other reasons? Why is it accelerated now, do you think?

utterances.speaker: KIRSANOW
utterances.utterance: Because, you know, I think some of it is because the policy prescription - the - think about how far the Democrats have gone to the Left, and it's difficult to get more than a certain percentage of voters to align themselves with those kinds of policy prescriptions. It's a lot easier to comprehend and appeal based on identity politics. If, for example, like what's her name - Alexandria Cortez were to go out and try to convince a voter how it is that extending Medicare to all or free college tuition is not going to bankrupt the economy, even most obtuse voter is going to laugh her off of the stage.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KIRSANOW
utterances.utterance: It's a lot easier to say vote for me because I am of whatever identity it may be, and make an appeal on that basis, and have media acolytes continue to echo that on a regular basis. A significant portion of this is because of Donald Trump and the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KIRSANOW
utterances.utterance: --continued attempts to paint Donald Trump and anyone who supports him as a racist. In some respects, it has been successful. I think it's backfired in other respects. But you're seeing something that they're going to test out big time in 2020.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes. No, I think that's really smart. Thank you making sense of that. Peter Kirsanow, one of our favorite guests.

utterances.speaker: KIRSANOW
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well Democrats have to choose a new Speaker of the House in just a couple of weeks. No choice. They got to do it. Nancy Pelosi brought the party to its biggest win in a long time. They've been out of power eight years. Now, they have power back. But a lot of Democrats say they don't want her as the Speaker. At least, one Left- leaning cable host is confused by this.

utterances.speaker: RACHEL ANNE MADDOW, THE RACHEL MADDOW SHOW HOST, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: The party picks up more seats in the House than at any time since the immediate aftermath of Watergate. And the party responds to that by maybe turfing out their leader in the House. We just had (ph) the biggest gain since Watergate. Pelosi must pay. Yes, Schumer (ph) you - you guys are good. I mean nothing against or for Schumer or against or for Pelosi but how does that math work?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well, you know (ph) that - that's not a crazy point, is it? Tammy Bruce is a radio host--

utterances.speaker: TAMMY K. BRUCE, ON-AIR CONTRIBUTOR, FOX NEWS, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S VOICE PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --President of Independent Women's Voice. She joins us tonight. So, Tammy, it seems to me like the Democratic Party may have reached the identity politics cul-de-sac--

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Yes, right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --where it's racist to keep Nancy Pelosi because she doesn't look like the emerging Democratic Party but it would be sexist to kick her out because she is the highest-ranking woman. So, what do they do?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: That's right. And also ageist, obviously--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean thank you, I forgot.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: --I mean, you want to go for - for anybody there, I - I think she is - she's, you know. Look, I value experience. Maddow is partly correct. But, at the same time, I thought Donald Trump was responsible for their success. I don't think Nancy Pelosi, according to the Democrats, had anything to do.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Good point.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: I want Donald Trump to be the Speaker of the House if it's about who, you know, so come on, let's be honest. Bottom line is, is that there is a - a strata there in the Democratic Party that understands that the establishment is out of touch that this is the same kind of - of dynamic that they've been dealing with for years that they have no answers and no prescription policies. And the people that said that they - that when they were running that they were going to vote against her it's because they were also running not as Democrats. They were pretending they weren't Democrats. They were assuring everyone we're not going to vote for the same old dynamic and the status quo, and that's what Nancy Pelosi is. And so, you know, look, they're - they - they understand the party's got to change. And yet, Nancy's also the only one who raises money. So, on the other hand--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: --all these socialists also want more money, and Nancy's the one to get it to them. So - so look, she is the best one for it. If they - you're right. No matter what they do, they're racists, sexist, ageists. And I don't know if we can fit homophobe in there somewhere. I'm sure - I'm sure that's a factor. But look, I - I've got my popcorn. I'm - I'm watching this. And I - maybe they should make Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez the - the Speaker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I'm rooting for her but--

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I would love that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --it's just interesting. I mean this is it - it's like one of the deep truths of life that you never suffer as much as when you get what you think you want--

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --so they took the House back. They took the House back.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: And all of a sudden they have to deal with each other. I mean--

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --that's the ultimate nightmare, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Well it's - it's that - it's the Frankenstein monster, right?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: They've created this. They're the - they're Dr. Frankenstein. They've - they thought they had this great idea. And then, you know, the lightning struck and they've got it. The monster woke up. And then, suddenly, the monster's chasing you around - around your office, and they don't - they're not quite sure, you know, it's a friend and maybe not - maybe - maybe not your friend. And but see this is--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes, maybe not.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: --maybe not your friend. But for - for those of us, of course, who care about the country, we see this as - as - as the charade that it is and they--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: --while they are, of course, Frank - my first book was about the racism, sexism and homophobia on the Left, we are going to hear like about that for the next two years as your first guest noted. This is the test run. This is about demonizing people. There will be no ideas.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: And the Republicans had better be ready to be able to counter that narrative and stand up for the American people led by the - the - the approach and the action of the President. We've got two years to get it right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: We've got to start right away.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You better toughen up a little bit, I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Tammy Bruce, thanks - thanks a lot.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Great to see you.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well there's another Florida recount. You know that has been going on for a week. It's in progress tonight. The Senate race between Rick Scott, the Republican, Bill Nelson, the Democrat, is still ongoing. Florida Secretary of State has ordered a manual recount. Craig Patrick is the Political Editor and Chief Investigator at Fox 13 in Tampa Bay. He's been on this for us since the beginning. He joins us once again tonight. Craig, what is going on?

utterances.speaker: CRAIG PATRICK, WTVT TAMPA BAY POLITICAL EDITOR AND CHIEF INVESTIGATOR
utterances.utterance: We have weird news in Florida. By the way, you also have a disputed race until now in the race for governor. But while Andrew Gillum gained on Ron DeSantis, he gained but one single vote, net. With that, that one is over though Gillum has not re-conceded. You're going to have Ron DeSantis now moving into the Governor's mansion. In the race for Senate--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PATRICK
utterances.utterance: --yes, there is now this hand recount because they are close enough to trigger it, which takes us into next week. That's the good news for Bill Nelson. The bad news for Bill Nelson is that he gained absolutely nothing from the machine recount that concluded today. In fact, he lost net votes to Rick Scott. Rick Scott ran up his lead through the first phase of the recount, which leaves Nelson in a position of being the political equivalent of Bruce Willis from Sixth Sense and that his career is over, he just does not know it yet, and he is playing that out. And you have more blunders in southeast Florida counties, the Democratic strongholds. You have Palm Beach County, there, the bad news is that their machines continued to - to sputter and fail and melt down. And Palm Beach County fell flat on its face and was unable to complete the recount, meaning, they just go back to their original results. If there's any good news there in Palm Beach County, it's that they're not Broward County to the south. And the good news, Tucker, in Broward County is that Brenda Snipes, after all the blunders said she finally did it today. She finally did something right that they after all the hand wringing were able to meet the deadline to complete their recount. She said they did it with minutes to spare and as she celebrated, the bad news is she forgot they had to transmit it to the state, and then they fumbled around where the computer couldn't figure out how to do it in time, they were two minutes late. And as per the law in Florida, the - the recount results in Broward County got rejected by the state.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You have conclusively convinced me not to run for office in Broward County. Thank you, Craig.

utterances.speaker: PATRICK
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to attempt it. Well, first, the press told you that the migrant Caravan wasn't even real. It didn't even exist. And then they told you it was so far away, it would basically never get here. Reality has intruded on that storyline and we have an update from Tijuana, Mexico, our southern border, after the break. Tucker takes on Univision anchor Enrique Acevedo.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: If there's one thing in the world you definitely shouldn't worry about, it's that fake Central American migrant Caravan, the xenophobic nationalists on Fox News have been trying to scare you into caring about or believing in, the whole thing is made up. It's a mirage. And even if it's sort of real, it's basically on the other side of the planet far, far away from here. Watch some of the most trusted people in America explain why your fears are ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: They're telling you, the - the existential threat to America is a bunch of poor refugees a 1,000 miles away. This group of folks, we don't even know where they are and they're way down there.

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, AMERICAN JOURNALIST, FORMER CNN CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Call this an invasion, it - it might be the most pathetic invasion of a country in world history if - if this were actually an invasion. But, of course, it's not.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN TONIGHT HOST, CNN
utterances.utterance: People he called invaders, even though they were a 1,000 miles away.

utterances.speaker: SAM STEIN, THE DAILY BEAST POLITICS EDITOR, MSNBC CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: The programming on the Caravan was propaganda.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Way down there, a 1,000 miles away. In other words, the Caravan is a lot like social security. It's something we might potentially need to think about someday. But for now, everything's totally fine, calm down. What liars they are? In fact, parts of that supposedly distant Caravan have already made it to the American border, and many of the illegal migrants in it have already hopped our shoddy defenses and entered our country. The famous people you just watch claim that would never happen haven't admitted they were wrong, intentionally or not. They haven't issued corrections, of course, and they never will. The election's over, so they're on to the next talking point. Meanwhile, the torrent continues. Well despite the Caravan being a myth, invented by President Trump to win a midterm, somehow, Univision Anchor, Enrique Acevedo managed to find it and he joins us tonight from Tijuana, Mexico. Enrique, I'm a little bit confused. So, last time I checked, which was just a couple of days ago, it seems like that Caravan was, in President Obama's terms, a 1,000 miles away, and they were walking. How did they get to Tijuana?

utterances.speaker: ENRIQUE ACEVEDO, ANCHOR, NOTICIERO UNIVISION LATE-NIGHT EDITION, SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT, THE FUSION MEDIA GROUP
utterances.utterance: The Caravan is very real. It's movement of people, thousands of people, around 5,000 have already arrived to Tijuana in the border with San Diego, Tucker, but it's not a national emergency or it is not - and it's not a threat to the national security of the United States. Most of the people that are part of this Caravan are just pushing strollers through Mexico. They're families--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --women, babies that are--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --just trying to get to the U.S. to the border to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but - but before we get to this subject--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --legally request asylum--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK, all right (ph), OK--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --something that President Trump is making--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK, but - but--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --much, much harder.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --before we get to the subjective (ph) part, I mean I'm - I'm an American. I'll decide whether it's a threat or not if that's OK. I just want to get to the practical part of this. So, we were told by anchors across the spectrum on television that the Caravan was a 1,000 miles away. They were walking. It was going to be weeks before they got to our border. I wake up this morning and there they are. How'd that happen? Did they run or did someone pay buses to take them up here? And you didn't tell us that part.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: It took them almost a month or over a month to get from Honduras to the U.S.-Mexico border. Not all of them have arrived. Some of them are still trying to get to this point, Tucker. And, yes, some of them were able to catch a ride and get on a bus, on trailers, on the back of buses carrying chickens and - and pigs. That's how they crossed--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no, no, wait, wait, hold on--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --and made their way through Mexico, you know (ph), some of them are still working and trying to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --no, that's not quite right. That's - that--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --reach the border what's (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --all right (ph), hold on, so you are saying that nobody chartered any buses to bring them up here because I think we have video showing chartered buses bringing them up here. And you're--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: I haven't seen anyone--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --the reporter on the scene. You don't think there were any chartered buses whatsoever?

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: I haven't seen anyone charting buses to bring them to the border. I've seen Mexican authorities, for example, here in Tijuana providing transportation from this point at the border to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Oh? No, no, no, not that - not that point - not that point--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --a more humanitarian setting just very--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --from - no, no, no, from the Yucatan through Oaxaca--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --close from here where 800 people are spending the night--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --so they're being transported in buses from here to there, but not from Oaxaca to the border.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. I don't - I don't think that's quite right. You might want to check your facts in that because it would be physically impossible for the group to move as a group on the back of chicken trucks, especially with the strollers you claim are there when, in fact, the eyewitness accounts we have suggest it's overwhelmingly young unattached men. But you're saying it's majority women and their babies and strollers, is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: I'm - I'm happy to share the footage with Fox News, the footage from our correspondent, Peroltradez (ph) who traveled with them in the back of a - a bus that usually carries chickens. That's how they got to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. That - that was - that was - that was one group--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --Cinnelo (ph) to Jalisco--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --others got rides (ph) in trailers, in the back of--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --pickup trucks, so that's, you know, that's the fact and we--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I - I - no, but I'm not quite sure that is the fact--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --we have proof of that and I'm happy to share it with you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --and I - I guess what I'm saying is what you're engaging in this propaganda designed to convince people of something that's not true. So, I think we both know that the majority of people, including people we just saw on the tape, moving from Honduras and Guatemala, are men, young men, without their--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: Right (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --wives and children, right? Or you're not going to admit that?

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: I don't think anyone was questioning the existence of the Caravan. What they were questioning is the label--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's composition (ph).

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --of being a national threat, some sort of emergency that needed--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No, no, let's get the facts and then hold on, hold on--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --the deployment of - of almost 6,000 troops--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I - I just want to get the - hold on, I just want, no--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --to the border which we have now. What's next?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but it's very hard, hold on, it's very hard--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --would (ph) we accept 6,000 troops in Chicago or in Manhattan? I mean--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK. OK. No, but hold on, it's very hard to make rational decisions about how to respond to something if you don't know what it is because everyone on TV is lying to you. And it's really clear that everyone on TV is lying to us. They told us that it was going to be weeks before this Caravan got here because they were walking. That was a lie. They told us it was mostly women and children. That's a lie. They said there was no one else helping the Caravan get here. That was a lie. And so, until we get to the facts, we can't know how to respond. So, let's stop with the lying and tell us what is actually going on. And you know it as well as I, it's mostly economic migrants looking for higher wages in the United States. I'm not attacking them. But that's the reality.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: Tucker, there's no organized effort to try to get these migrants from Honduras to the border, to the U.S.-Mexico border. I know Vice President Pence said that there were forces in Latin America from the Left and Venezuela financing this and making it some sort of a conspiracy to undermine the U.S. government. But the reality is that these people are fleeing Honduras, 300 Hondurans are leaving their country every day, and they're doing it--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --because the levels of violence and the levels of extreme poverty that they face there, so--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So - so let me just ask you a (ph) question--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --what would you do if you had your family in that situation?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --so just to be - before we get to the--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: Of course, this is not ideal (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --last - last question.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --this is a humanitarian crisis. And again--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --all the governments involved should act like it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. You're saying, and I just want to get you on the record saying this that there are no groups funded by governments or big NGOs helping this group of people move from Central America to where they are now, Tijuana, and to get across the border (ph)? Nobody is helping them. It's all organic. That's what you're saying.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: In all our - in all our reporting, since this Caravan started, not only this one, the others that follow and that will keep following them, we haven't found any evidence of any government involved in founding or - funding or financing this effort to try to get these people from Honduras to the U.S.-Mexico border.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well you just said the Mexican authorities--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: Of course, NGOs are trying to provide humanitarian help--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --Mexican people have been kind enough--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --hope you get (ph)--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --to provide some humanitarian help--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --all right (ph)--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --but there's no government or state force behind this. This - we - we--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Or - or NGO?

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: --haven't found that, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: NGO, I mean, look, we all know what's exactly what's going on. I just - I just want to have you on the record so we can invite you back and we can talk through your previous claims and compare them to the evidence that we are in the process of gathering, and I can't wait for that. Thank you so much, Enrique, for joining us tonight, from Tijuana, Mexico.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Two of America's richest and most Liberal states are giving a huge tax break to the world's richest man. Taxpayers are subsidizing Jeff Bezos, and Democratic politicians are applauding. What exactly is going on? We've got details after the break. Tucker takes on tech entrepreneur Eric Schiffer.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well, for about a 100 years, the Democratic Party was the party of America's working class. Not anymore. Now, the Democratic Party is the party of merciless corporate power, of Google, and Facebook, and the rest, and they'll punish you if you get in their way, as you know. Latest example, New York and Northern Virginia, two of the Bluest parts of this country showered promises and billions and billions in taxpayer breaks on Jeff Bezos. He runs Amazon. In return, both those states are getting a new Amazon headquarters. It's a great deal for Bezos. Not that he needs it. He's already the richest man on planet Earth. But, what about taxpayers? Eric Schiffer is a tech entrepreneur. He's CEO of the Patriarch Organization. And he joins us tonight. Eric, thanks a lot for coming on.

utterances.speaker: ERIC SCHIFFER, PATRIARCH CHAIRMAN, TECH ENTREPRENEUR
utterances.utterance: My pleasure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, it's - it's just not clear to me--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: You know, I - I came--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --why - why would New York, for example, and Virginia is in on this too, but New York paid more, why do they need to pay $3 billion in effect in taxpayer dollars to the richest man in the world for the privilege of having the company moved to New York?

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well, look, I came on because the state representative there, Cortez, made a statement and made comments basically saying that she didn't want to take Amazon's jobs in New York because perhaps it wasn't going to be unionizable, etcetera and you agreed with Cortez in this situation--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No, no, I didn't. I - I wasn't--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --and in fact we (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I - but - but hold on--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --I - well you actually you did--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --no, wait--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I'm - I'm sitting right here. I can tell you what I agree with. I'm never ashamed of that. I agreed with the point that she made, and I don't often agree with her, but I thought it was a fair point. Why is New York, which is crumbling, I'm there a lot, you may be there now, the city's falling apart. It smells. The subways break. It's disgusting. Why would the city be spending $3 billion to the richest man in the world? Why wouldn't that money go to, I don't know, fixing the subways, just throwing out there, cleaning up the streets or plowing the snow or helping the people who already live there? I'm just confused.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well, look, I typically and rarely, if ever, agree with the socialist and, certainly don't, in this situation, on many levels. I think what happened here and I think we all can recall that Amazon had an open bid across the country, in which--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --all these states could compete. And everyone did. And they did because people still want jobs--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right. And I agree.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --across the country. They still want good-paying jobs. And frankly, I think, that goes for New York and even Arlington, people in the Bronx, and in Queens, they haven't had investment and jobs in about a 100 years. And here comes Amazon saying, "Look, we're going to put - we're considering putting jobs in your state, in your city." And these - and the politicians that run the cities recognize it's a competitive situation, and all cities, all major cities have for years, for decades, competed for incentives to get jobs as they should. Look, the tax cut passed by President Trump, which I supported, it was a big proponent. I mean a big component of - of the tax cut was - was jobs. It caused businesses--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: But - but you're not going to get (ph)--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --including some of the big--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --wait, hold on, you're - you're not clear (ph)--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --let me just finish--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I think we're talking past each other. I'm not--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --my point, please.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --wait, hold on, I'm not against jobs--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't think we are--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I'm of course (ph) for jobs but--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --I haven't finished--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but it's not Amazon - but hold on, it's not Amazon doing the investing. It's the taxpayers of New York and Virginia, who are investing in Jeff Bezos against their will. They're paying the richest man in the world--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --$3 billion for the privilege of having him move to a city he didn't build. I'm just confused. Why is that a good deal for New York? I know it's a good deal for Bezos.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well first of all the - first of all, they're not handing a check to Bezos. They're handing a check to Amazon, which is a public company that you may own shares and anyone on the - watches the show could own shares in, so this is for the public, in general, and it's a public company. It's an American company, and a - and a good one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's not an American - it's not an American--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: And in this--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --wait, hold on, slow down, it's not an American company. It's - it's not owned - no, it's not an American company. It's owned by people around the world--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well this was found--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --including sovereign wealth funds of our enemies. So it's not--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --I got to - I got to cut you off here, Tucker (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --in any sense an American company.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --Tucker. Tucker, come on. This was founded in the United States. It was one - it's one of the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well I'm aware.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --one of the great country--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It could only have been founded here--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --one of the great countries in the world--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --with our justice system and our patent protection--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --that allows for great technology--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but it's not American--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --well you--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --it's not - you think it's loyal to America?

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --well it was founded by Americans--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You think it's trying (ph) to help America?

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --it was - it--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Come on, it was found--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No, you come on.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --it was founded by Americans. It certainly was - it certainly is a big contributor to tax (ph) here in America, there's no question, and jobs, significant jobs. And I think that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. But - but let me just - will you just--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --what I was trying - my point that I was trying to make--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --please answer my question?

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --Tucker--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Look, I mean, look, I don't think everything about Amazon is bad. I think they do a great job. I use Amazon. I mean they're huge because they do a good job. But my question is why would the Democratic Party hand the richest man in the world $3 billion a year to move to New York without asking what the taxpayers think in a city that is literally falling apart? That's not a fair question? I think it is a fair question.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well I - I think most states and most cities wanted Amazon to come. In fact, there were many other states that superseded that amount by significant levels. I mean New Jersey--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You don't see that as a little pathetic?

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --and others (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I mean what - why wouldn't--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I mean, look, if you see Amazon--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --I see it - I see it (ph) as--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --as an American company--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --part of the capital--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --the capital? Really? This is not the capitalism I was promised. I don't know. I mean so the capitalism is--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well but - but - but, Tucker--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --pull the (ph) biggest scam you can--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --but, Tucker--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --and run away laughing? I mean that's not capitalism--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Actually, no, no--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --as far as I'm concerned.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --actually, what I think it is, Tucker, is it's investing in jobs. The - the bottom line from this is the end. It's different than socialism like Cortez is for that you support it. The difference is--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I'm not supporting socialism--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --is that this is going to actually bring money back to the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I would like capitalism. There's nothing--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --cities in the end. But, Tucker--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --capitalist about a monopoly--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --you're talking about--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --or some - some creepy billionaire--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --investment.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --suborning politicians on an inside deal that I'd had no say in. How's that capitalism? That's something much lower than capitalism.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: Well it's - it's capitalism when a city invests to get jobs and actually gets more money back from tax revenue.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well we'll - we'll see.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: That makes sense.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: It's no different than the tax cut. We're - we're getting more jobs. It's growing jobs.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Oh yes (ph).

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: And I think that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: And a helipad too. And I guess--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --America could benefit in the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --helipad--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --right cases (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --in that in that (ph)--

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: --with investment.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right. OK. The helipad, that's my favorite part. Eric, thank you very much. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: SCHIFFER
utterances.utterance: My pleasure. Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well, unfortunately, a heartwarming story has been exposed as a hoax. It may tell us something broader about America we might like to know. Mark Steyn, one of the smartest people on planet Earth joins us after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well if you are compiling a list, you'd have to say that Al Sharpton would be one of the most, maybe the most, successful race baiter in America in the past 40 years. He's certainly in the Hall of Fame. He's made a lucrative career targeting people for the color of their skin, their religion, and other factors. Democrats will tell you they are the party that is against racism. They may even call you a racist. But you know they don't mean it. Why? Because they love Al Sharpton to this day. For example, at a National Action Network event, and that's Sharpton's group, just yesterday, top Democrats lined up to prostrate themselves before the altar of Al Sharpton. Not a joke, watch this.

utterances.speaker: KIRSTEN ELIZABETH GILLIBRAND, JUNIOR UNITED STATES SENATOR, NEW YORK
utterances.utterance: That's why you have leaders like the Reverend Al Sharpton who will not give up and will not give in and will never let it go.

utterances.speaker: BERNARD SANDERS, POLITICIAN, JUNIOR UNITED STATES SENATOR, VERMONT
utterances.utterance: It seems that whenever there is a crisis, Al Sharpton and many of you are there.

utterances.speaker: NANCY PELOSI, MINORITY LEADER OF THE UNITED STATES HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
utterances.utterance: Reverend Sharpton, thank you for saving America.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Whenever there's a crisis, Al Sharpton is there. Well, that's for sure. That's the understatement of the year. Thank you for saving America, they say. Did he save America before or after he incited the shooting at Freddy's Fashion Mart? I don't know. Check Google. You decide. But any (ph) case, save that tape for the next time some Liberal calls you a racist. Hilarious. Well East Coast opinion columnists may routinely denigrate them but Americans remain a caring, generous people, the most caring and most generous people in the world, by far. And, unfortunately, some people take advantage of that. A year ago, Mark D'Amico and Kate McClure raised over $400,000 on the GoFundMe site. They did it allegedly in the name of a man called Johnny Bobbitt. He's homeless. They said he had helped them out when they ran out of gas on the highway. Well later, Bobbitt accused the couple of keeping all that money for themselves. Now, in a new twist, authorities say the entire story was a hoax from day one and all three of them are facing charges. What can we learn from this? Author and Columnist Mark Steyn joins us tonight for an overview. What do you make of this, Mark?

utterances.speaker: MARK STEYN, AUTHOR, COLUMNIST, STEYNONLINE.COM
utterances.utterance: Well, I did think this was the craziest story of the day, Tucker, until I heard your last segment. And I'm not sure actually giving 400 grand to a homeless guy isn't on balance marginally less insane than giving $3 billion--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I (ph)--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: --to Jeff Bezos. So there - there is that. I - I have to say, you're right. Americans, all the polls of global charity show it, Americans are the most generous people on the planet.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: And I think it would be sad if charity and that generosity were just to become part of a - a kind of going viral on social media thing. I - this story smelt--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: --crummy to me a year ago, when it was a feel-good story. And not to go all H. L. Mencken on you, but I - I - it's a feel-good story for me now, just because it's sort of confirmed--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Ha-ha--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: --my slightly dark view of human nature.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --ha-ha.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: I love everything about this story. I love the way it's - it was an obvious set-up from the start. I loved - I loved the way people just sort of went bananas for it. I mean it's not a good idea to give someone who's sleeping on an interstate ramp $400,000. He only got about 75 of it. He was spending about two grand a day. Meanwhile, this other couple just took off with it. They bought a BMW. They went to Vegas and - and blew it on the fancy suite at the Mandalay Bay or whatever it was. The - the homeless guy then sued them. The homeless guy has a lawyer. That's fantastic. America has as many lawyers, statistic this is, America is - has as many lawyers as the rest of the planet combined. And there's so many of them that even a homeless guy has a lawyer. I love everything about this story.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Ha-ha.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: I'm thinking of launching a GoFundMe campaign to raise money to buy a bridge for creepy porn lawyer to sleep under.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Ha-ha.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: That's how enthused I am by this story.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You know what? He may wind up under one anyway even without your help. The great Mark Steyn--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I knew that you would see a bright side to that dark tale, and you did always (ph).

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: It is - it is a dark tale. But we should all rejoice. Give money locally, Tucker. Save your community before you go and do it on social media.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You know, that's - that is - that is - that is the take-away. That is a deep and true point. Ask how your kids feel about you before you go anywhere else.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Mark. Great to see you.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Time now for Final Exam. Question, always the same. Can you beat the experts at remembering what happened this week in the news? After the break, we'll be back. Which one of our news experts was paying more attention to this week's news events?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: We've waited a long time. But it's the best time of the week. It's time for Final Exam where the news experts assemble to see who has been paying closest attention to the news over the last week, and who is the true champion of news knowledge. Tonight, quite a matchup, defending champion is one of our own Chief National Correspondent, the great Ed Henry. The challenger, tonight, a familiar face to viewers of this show, from The Federalist, Senior Editor, Mollie Hemingway. Normally, I get a sense of who - I - I'm not quite sure who's going to win here and I'm not even going to venture a guess thing (ph).

utterances.speaker: ED HENRY, CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You know the rules. I'm going to repeat them for our viewers. Hands on buzzers. I ask the questions. First one to buzz in gets to answer the question. Critically, you must wait until I finish asking the question in order to answer it. You can answer once I acknowledge you by saying your name. Each correct answer worth one point. If you get it wrong, we detract a point because we are cruel. Best of five wins.

utterances.speaker: MOLLIE ZIEGLER HEMINGWAY, SENIOR EDITOR, THE FEDERALIST, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: I brought some--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Be prepared.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: --I brought some stuff.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.utterance: I mean this is (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I just want to say it for the record and - and for the marketing department, I had no role in this at all.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: No. I just I bought a bunch for Christmas and--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: This is Ed Henry--

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: --you know (ph), if there's a close call--

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's good so (ph) it's unbelievable. Question one. The great Marvel Comics Illustrator and Creator Stan Lee passed away this week. He was 95 years old. He was the brain behind characters like Iron Man, The Hulk, and someone called Insect Man. Thankfully, he reconsidered and changed name of that character to what? Ed Henry?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: Spiderman.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Spiderman. Are you sure?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: To the tape we go.

utterances.speaker: STAN LEE, AMERICAN COMIC BOOK WRITER, EDITOR, PUBLISHER
utterances.utterance: And I said (ph) gee, what if a guy could stick to walls like an insect? That sounds good. So, I started trying to think of some names. Insect Man? No. Spiderman? Ooh, that sounds dramatic.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: With great power--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: There you go, Spiderman.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: --comes great responsibility.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Very good, OK. One-Zero. Question two. We thought it would never happen to our business. This was supposed to happen only to people who work in factories but it's in fact happening. The first artificial intelligence news anchor is now on the air. A very human-looking AI news man is reading headlines in which East Asian country? Robot news anchor where?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: Little bit of China.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: China. Is it China?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The Chinese state media showing off their newest--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: --news anchor. There's something (ph) different about him. He's not a person.

utterances.speaker: ENGLISH ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: Hello everyone. I'm an English Artificial Intelligence Anchor. This is my very first day in Xinhua News Agency.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: The robot news anchors are very obedient

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.utterance: They're not as good as you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: They're not as good as me but they stick to the script. There's no ad-libbing. All right, good guess, by the way. Question three, multiple choice. This week, Disney World permanently banned a man from the park after he was photographed waving a Trump 2020 sign while on which one of their rides? Was it A, Pirates of the Caribbean, B, It's a Small World, C, Splash Mountain? Mollie Hemingway.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY

utterances.utterance: It didn't seem like (ph). Question four, another multiple choice. Democrats are now saying their fight against the President is not about politics or policy.
